snippet.title: With Youth Unemployment At 55 Percent, Spanish Students Take To The Streets
snippet.description: Spain's Popular Party, led by Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, passed a $4 billion cut to public education in May and has proposed an overhaul of the education system. MADRID — On most weekday afternoons, 21-year-old Spanish student John Suarez is sitting in class at his school on the outskirts of [...] read »

snippet.title: Spanish Bulls Chase Euro Higher
snippet.description: Forex markets are eyeing their brethren, the bond market, for direction. Spain and France both come to the bond market today and whether they are successful or not will ultimately decide the direction that the EUR will take in the medium term. Obviously, the ‘single’ currency’s recovery over the past two quarters has been strongly correlated to [...] read »

snippet.title: Bad Timing for a Royal Spanish Scandal
snippet.description: If this scandal had happened in better economic times it probably would have been shut down without a stretch, as are most embarrassments relating to Europe's various royal families. A few phone calls in the name of the king, the queen or other royal representatives to some privileged connections or [...] read »

snippet.title: Spanish, Italian Economies Show Signs of Life
snippet.description: Eurozone growth slowed in July, as the debt, financial, and unemployment crises continue to cripple the continents economy. Data released overnight showed that the European economy slowed in July from June ever so slightly. However, peripheral nations including Spain and Italy actually showed some signs of life. The Eurozone Purchasing Managers [...] read »

snippet.title: Why More Money Printing Will Increase Unemployment
snippet.description: (Image credit: AFP/Getty Images via @daylife) The developed world’s central banks are now foolishly preparing for a full assault on their respective currencies in an attempt to lower unemployment rates. Spurring these central bankers into action is persistently anemic markets and employment data, which they believe can be rectified by [...] read »

snippet.title: Unemployment Rate Falls, Stocks Rise on Mixed Economic News
snippet.description: Mario Draghi, ECB President (Photo credit: World Economic Forum) This is a guest post by Craig Birk, director of portfolio management at Personal Capital. In typical bull market fashion, stocks rose on mixed economic news. Friday’s monthly jobs report, the last before the Presidential election, was better than expected, pushing the unemployment [...] read »

snippet.title: Spanish Woman Commits Suicide As Foreclosure Agents Walk Into Her Apartment
snippet.description: A woman jumped to her death in Spain as foreclosure agents forced open her door on Friday. This isn't an isolated case, last month, a man hung himself hours before being foreclosed on, while another attempted, and failed, to commit suicide before foreclosure. read »

snippet.title: Spanish Bank Stress Tests Dramatically Underestimate Capital Shortfall
snippet.description: The Spanish banking sector audits charged with figuring out how much capital was needed to shore those banks up in a stress scenario failed to represent a truly pessimistic situation, thus underestimating how much capital they actually need. read »
